newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: ANALYSIS-INTERIM RESULTS FAIL TO STIR LITHUANIAN BOURSE.
newsitem.headline: ANALYSIS-INTERIM RESULTS FAIL TO STIR LITHUANIAN BOURSE.

text.p: The interim results are in from the Vilnius bourse's premier five-stock official list and they are all in the black.
But the market's response to the spate of promising figures has been snail-paced at best and throws its problems into sharp releif, dealers and analysts said on Thursday.
They include low levels of local liquidity, a limited foreign presence and the failure of many companies to convince investors that will be profitable in the long-term.
"Domestic investors are too small to move the market and foreign institutional investors are not present," said Kestutis Kupshys, a dealer with Mendes Prior Europe.
"The market is developing, but very slowly," said Kupshys. "Even the release of half-year results is not a factor that can change that fundamental situation."
"This is still a very young market; it doesn't work like a developed market," said Saulius Racevichius, director of the financial brokerage department at Vilniaus Bank.
Brokers say that results are important but that most companies lack proven track records that could justify quick decisions based on interim results.
Many of the lesser known companies lack transparancy and the market is often wary of their announcements.
And good results are expected from the leading companies so few people get excited about them.
"There has been nothing unexpected for an investor who is following the (official list) companies because they are transparent ," said one broker.

Lithuania's bourse did see a mild recovery of turnover in the wake of six-month results by the country's premier commercial banks, Vilniaus Bank and Hermis Bank, but other blue chips have failed to stir the market.
Rokishkis Cheese announced on Monday its profits rose to 9.467 million litas from 1.253 million litas in the same period last year.
The market's response?
Rokishkis shares held steady at 42 litas on Tuesday before slipping to 41.50 litas on Wednesday.
In what may be a delayed reaction, it firmed to 43 litas on Thursday.
Brokers say they expect Rokishkis share prices to live up to the company's results but stress that it will take time.
"In the long term, Rokishkis share prices will increase," said Paulius Dumshe, an analyst with Suprema.
But brokers say the situation is improving.
"If you look at last year, it took something like three or four months (for the market to react to results)," Dumshe said.
Reaction time now takes "up to one month."
"It depends on the company," Dumshe said. "In the case of Vilniaus Bank, it was the first and most known bank in Lithuania, so reaction time is short."
"The market is still undervalued and underdeveloped," Kupshys said. "But that's the time for the investment process to begin."
-- Burton Frierson, Vilnius newsroom +370 2 22 35 18
